Posts.Content: My BCN told me I was going to get aches and pains everywhere and she was right. I was particularly worried about my armpit leading up to the op as it was aching but the nodes were clear, it must have been in my head. I think I become hypersensitive after being given the diagnosis xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed but still waiting for tests

Posts.Content: Thank you, I’m going to get mine done too and I don’t want those big trendy ones either lol, will be happy if they can copy what I’ve got now xx
Posts.Title: Eyrbrows still thin

Posts.Content: Was that Microblading Winney?
Posts.Title: Eyrbrows still thin

Posts.Content: Hi LucyB, I’m in a very similar situation to you in so many ways. I’m a single parent with a 10 year old daughter and two parents from her class died of cancer last year, one of whom she knew very well and adored, and we went to her funeral. I know it’s going to terrify my daughter. I’m grade 3 with a tiny lump (<1cm) which is being removed in two week’s time and I’m HER2+ so chemo looks inevitable for me. I’m not planning on telling my daughter until I really have to, which will be nearer chemo time, because by that time we will know everything there is to know about it so will be dealing with facts rather than if’s, but’s and maybe’s. This also gives all the adults time to adjust which I think will help her, if she sees the adults are scared that will not help at all! I love what sortitout says, that telling her daughter after the cancer was removed felt easier than than saying it’s still there, and that her daughter appreciates that. It makes so much sense and reassures me that I’m doing the right thing. I have an older son who I’ve already told, it was the hardest thing I’ve ever done but he took it fine and is getting on with it like me. All my fear and worry for him was for nothing, thankfully. I think that, while there’s nothing good about having breast cancer, we are actually very lucky that it’s early/small/low grade so I’m focusing on the positives of my situation, I hope you can too. My surgeon and nurse said the entire team are very confident that they will be able to put my mind at rest after the op as all signs so far are that it hasn’t spread to the lymph nodes. I’m not going to worry between now and that day because worrying is not going to change anything at all, it would just ruin the next two weeks of our lives. I am also relieved that I’m having the op first so have more time to prepare myself for chemo. I feel like I’ve been given a breather so I’m taking it with both hands. I first found my lump in July last year but the doctor sent me away then saying it just felt like breast tissue to her and to come back if it changes. It didn’t feel like breast tissue to me and the lump WAS the change so I’ve been worrying ever since, I’m actually relieved that it’s being dealt with finally and that it’s not out of control like I’d feared. Best of luck to you, be strong and be positive. Of course you can do this Xx
Posts.Title: Test Results

Posts.Content: We certainly have got this (in the ‘you got this sense’ lol)!  Ignorance is bliss, let’s let our girls be carefree for as long as possible, no need to ruin their fun for now and it does help us to keep calm and carry on. You may not even have to tell her if no chemo, I wouldn’t tell mine if lumpectomy and radiotherapy only. Really hoping it goes that way for you xx
Posts.Title: Test Results

Posts.Content: I agree with Chloecat. I was going to ask them to postpone my chemo for a couple of weeks (I thought RT would be first after op) to go on holiday. Then I realised it was chemo first so a delay of 7 weeks was a bit much lol. A holiday will do you the world of good before chemo, you deserve it after going through all this x
Posts.Title: can you put treatment on hold for a couple of weeks?

Posts.Content: You'd think you could celebrate that success from chemo but it's been too successful, who'd have thought that was even a think! It's a shame they can't just go straight to radiotherapy if the cancer's gone. Has that been considered? A friend of a friend had a tumour that completely disappeared through chemo, she had no surgery, did have radiotherapy and was given the all clear but she's on Herceptin so I suppose that's another line of defence that you're presumably not having? Maybe that's why surgery wasn't necessary for her?
Posts.Title: Looking for anyone in similar situation, marker not put in during...

Posts.Content: Oh dear, how do you feel about that? Mixed emotions I’m sure xx
Posts.Title: Looking for anyone in similar situation, marker not put in during...

Posts.Content: Hi Restory, I’ve got people around who are ready to step in if needed but my son (20) is here to help with school runs, cooking etc, also my next door neighbour who went through chemo last year is going to keep a close eye on me. And my mum is not far and pretty much wants to move in lol. But in all honesty I just want to get on with in peace, if I can do school runs and cook up some food on good days I’ll be happy. The rest of the time I can do nothing and suffer lol. I’ve actually been quite lucky, I found out today I’m getting the gentler chemo and even though I’m expecting to feel crap the onco reckons I should be able to do the basics if (I don’t have any major issues) and I’ll be able to get myself to hospital etc so I’m optimistic about getting through it. But as I say, my son is here and he drives so I think we’ll cope. Onco told me about the success of Herceptin today, my surgeon had too, as far as they’re concerned I’ll put this behind me and get on with my life so I’ve decided not to waste my life worrying about losing it, which of course was the major fear.  I think waiting till you know everything definitely helps when it comes to telling the kids, knowledge is power and it won’t be as bad as the things you’re imagining. When you’ve got your treatment plan things start to look clearer and more positive. I told my son straightaway but I’ve put off telling my daughter because 2 parents from her old class died of cancer last year (not breast) and it’ll worry her. She also started a new school last week so I want her to settle in first. I will tell her the weekend before it starts that I’m having chemo to stop it from coming back but I don’t have it now.  I’ll be thinking of you on Thursday and hoping for good results. Give yourself time to get over the shock before you decide to do anything, it is a frightening time but honestly, when you know what you’re dealing with it really does get easier xx Sorry for hijacking the thread Tingk x
Posts.Title: Looking for anyone in similar situation, marker not put in during...

Posts.Content: No you can’t ignore the success of the chemo and if they feel the mastectomy is necessary then it’s best to go with it. I think I would worry if they didn’t take something away so at least you’ll know you’ve done as much prevention as possible. Good luck with it x
Posts.Title: Looking for anyone in similar situation, marker not put in during...

Posts.Content: Rainbowdreaming I’m quite similar to you, I was diagnosed in March and had a lumpectomy at the beginning of April. I have a 20 year old son and 10 year old daughter, I told my son a few days later and he’s much the same as me... take in the facts and crack on with it! However, 2 parents from my daughter’s class died of cancer last year, one of whom she was very close to, very upset about and we went to her funeral, so the thought of telling her breaks my heart.  I start my chemo in the next week or two, I find out on Monday when and what etc. so I will tell her before chemo starts. She knew I was having surgery on my booby but didn’t ask for details (unlike her) so I left it at that.  I was worrying about telling my daughter from day 1 but had decided to wait till chemo was confirmed. Then I read a comment from another mum with a 14 year old who said she told her daughter between surgery and chemo because that way she could say she HAD cancer but doesn’t have it anymore and that chemo is preventative rather than treating cancer. Her daughter later said she was glad she was told that way. This reassured me that I was doing it the right way and luckily my cancer hadn’t gone beyond the lump so it is true account now. Another thing I’ve come to realise is that I’m much more comfortable and confident about the whole situation now and so is everyone around me, so there will be much less fear in me when it comes to telling her, and in anyone else she speaks to about it. The last thing I want is for her to be scared and I know I’m in a better place to reassure her now.  I hope this helps. Just wanted to add to others, I don’t think it’s weird at all to be okayish with the diagnosis. I was weirdly relieved when I got mine and knew that it was being dealt with rather than just me knowing and worrying about the worst case scenarios. I had found it in July and was sent away from the doctor without a referral, by the time I was diagnosed I was beside myself. The experts know what they’re doing, once you’re in their hands you’re going to be fine.
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Good luck to you both tomorrow x
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Sorry me again! Just wanted to say I agree with toxophilite in that hiding it takes so much energy. My worst time throughout this whole thing was the anxiety of telling my mum and son. In the end I couldn’t tell my mum myself as I couldn’t bear to see her face, a close family friend did it for me and my mum understood why. Get the older important people out the way so you can settle down yourself, worrying about telling them just creates more stress, the fear of telling them goes when they know so is one less thing to worry about. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: I’ll be in the May chemo group too. I find out tomorrow when it starts and which type, just know that it’s 12 x weekly chemo plus Herceptin.  I’d never heard of an eyebrow stamp before but I’m ordering one now lol, thanks for that x
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Omg that sounded harsh... I meant I couldn’t bear to see how much it upset her on her face.
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: It’s horrible isn’t it  my nan (mum’s mum) died of cancer and my stepdad (since I was a baby) died of it too, both within 10 weeks of diagnosis. I knew what it would do to her and I just couldn’t cope with that on top of the diagnosis and telling my kids, I felt like I was suffocating. She’s fine with it all now but it did take her to come into an appointment with me and hear it from the consultant’s mouth that I’m lucky, this is procedure and I’ll put it behind me. She has definitely taken the whole thing much harder than me and I completely understand as I’m glad it’s happening to me and not my kids. I worry about my mum and what it will do to her probably more than my kids, she’s been through enough I thought I might hide it from everyone if I could but I was told straightaway that I was HER2+ so chemo very likely, so I had to tell them. But you’re right, they know when something’s up and she had been saying to people that she knew something was wrong and that I was worried about something but she didn’t know what. There was a little resentment that I hadn’t told her about the lump and biopsy and that she wasnt prepared but she understands that I didn’t want to worry her unnecessarily. There’s so many little nuances that you don’t even begin to imagine when you know someone is going through this. I can’t imagine what it was like for people before the internet age and access to these forums and information at your own pace from the comfort of your own home when you’re ready. Being able to share and read experiences is absolutely priceless in this situation. Xx
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy-B, sorry you’ve been told you need chemo  it feels like another punch in the stomach when you’re told but I think, like with all of these bits of news, we need a few days to get our head around it then we feel a bit better. I’m starting chemo in a couple of weeks, I see it as a necessary evil which will give me more confidence going forward knowing that I’ve done everything I can to prevent it coming back, my onco calls it insurance. I will be joining you in the May chemo club. Best of luck to you Sarah xx
Posts.Title: Going to be starting chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Restory, my situation is different to yours but I've had the same worries as you're having now, we all have so we completely understand how you're feeling. I'm a single parent of two, my eldest is 20 and his dad lives hundreds of miles away and has never been a proper dad, even when he lived with us. My youngest is 10 and she's only seen her father a handful of times in her life, the last time was about 7 years ago and we've had no contact for 6 years years now. So of course I worry about their future as I'm all they've got parentwise. Waiting for information is the most frightening time because you don't know what you're dealing with, the possibilities are endless and the mind wanders out of control. Once you have all the the facts it's easier to look forward because you know what it is and what can be done and you can start getting on with getting rid of it. I still haven't told my daughter, she started a new school last week so I wanted to let her settle there before I tell her. I've had my lump removed and all the results were great, nothing like what I was worrying about, not even close! So now I'm able to tell her I had cancer but it's been taken out and the chemo is to stop it coming back. I've also realised that after having those weeks to come to terms with it myself and having all the facts, I'm much calmer and confident about everything so am in a better place emotionally to tell her. If I'd told her at the beginning I would have been a mess and probably would have terrified her. You know your daughter better than anyone else and you will find the best way to tell her. Try not to think that far ahead at this stage, concentrate on one thing at a time which for you right now is getting the biopsy results. My BCN told me to take it one step at a time when I was racing ahead with if's but's and maybe's, it was the best bit of advice I've had. Try to concentrate on one thing at a time otherwise it quickly becomes overwhelming. Best of luck to you, I hope you get good results from your biopsy xx
Posts.Title: mum of only child fear

Posts.Content: I'll be starting chemo in two weeks and was wondering about school and chickenpox. When two parents from my daughter's last school were having chemo the school were obsessed with being informed about chickenpox because of it, a letter was sent to every parent about it at first and it was mentioned on every new term letter and newsletter. I'm just wondering if her new school should be doing this. My daughter (10) has never had chickenpox and my mum doesn't remember me having them but we've both been exposed several times over the years, don't know if that's even relevant lol.  Has anyone else had exposure to chickenpox mentioned specifically? I'll mention it at my next appointment but that's not till the 10th.
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks Cathy, I spoke to the chemo team and they said ideally it would be best for her to have the vaccine at least a week before but still okay if a bit closer as the amount of virus is so low. I've called the surgery (my daughter has a different surgery to me) and they're more concerned about getting someone else to do it because they don't want to pay for it!!! They're trying to get her sent to hospital for it?!?! I'm waiting for them to call back, if they try to wriggle out of it I'm going to point out that my daughter has been registered with them for 6 years and has had less appointments than that over those years and only one prescription, all her vaccinations were done before she was registered there so I don't see why it's a problem to pay for this one now! What is wrong with these people, Superdrug is selling them for £65 so they can't be that expensive.
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: That does help, thank you. I'll give the surgery a call now.  Sarah x
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Such sad news of your dear sister machka10, I'm so sorry for your loss.  xx
Posts.Title: No tears left

Posts.Content: They didn’t call back :-/ I’ll call them Tuesday and kick up a BIG fuss. Since being diagnosed I don’t like to rely on luck lol, the way my luck’s been this will be the year she gets chickenpox! I’m just disgusted that their priority is to waste time trying to worm out of paying for it, it’s shameful and I’m going to tell them that! I’ve got a bee in my bonnet about it now lol x
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Make a fuss, do it! I was sent away by a locum GP (I didn’t know was a locum) without a referral because ”it feels like breast tissue”, this delayed my diagnosis by 7 months. The locum said to come back if it changes and because I felt it daily for 4 months I couldn’t notice the change, after 3 months of strictly not touching it I realised it was bigger. I was so worried throughout that time I can’t believe now that I never went back, it seems insane now but I didn’t want to make a nuisance of myself or seem neurotic somehow. Now I wish I was neurotic! Luckily those 7 months don’t seem to have made much difference but my advice to anyone would be to make that fuss if you’re not happy, it’s not worth the risk not to, and in some cases earlier detection can mean no chemo xx
Posts.Title: Pain in my left breast - consultant not interested

Posts.Content: Where are you getting your funky wigs from Sammystaff? Love them! I might as well get something to put on my head for that price in case it does fall out.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
